title: 104_hr1005
content: The Act titled "National Language Act of 1995" designates English as the official language. The National Language Act of 1995 designates English as the official language of the United States government for all official activities, publications, and materials, with exceptions for religious purposes, foreign language training, and language learning programs in schools. SEC. 3. TERMINATION OF BILINGUAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS. The Bilingual Education Act and the Office of Bilingual Education and Minority Languages Affairs are repealed and terminated, respectively. Unexpended funds from the Act will be recaptured. Transitional provisions allow for the completion of programs during the current school year. The Bilingual Education Act is repealed, and unexpended funds will be recaptured. Transitional provisions allow for the completion of programs until the most recent school year. The Secretary of Education may assist in transitioning children to Special Alternative Instructional Programs that do not use their native language. The Bilingual Education Act is repealed, including bilingual voting requirements. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended by repealing bilingual election requirements under Section 203 and striking subsection (f) of Section 4. Conforming amendments remove references to Section 203 and Section 4 in various sections of the Act. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended by removing guarantees related to voting rights in certain sections. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to require all citizenship ceremonies to be conducted in English. This Act and its amendments do not preempt any state laws.
